Case are a UK-based manufacturer of communications equipment. I joined Case as part of the wide area networking department, primarily on their 'DCX' range of equipment.
I worked on a variety of projects at Case covering maintaining and enhancing their existing products as well as analysing, designing and implementing new products.
At Case, I worked on several WAN products, which enhanced my skills in the production of real-time embedded applications. My responsibilities involved analysis and design - using the Yourdon/Ward-Mellor methodology - and coding. The coding was in 'C' for the Motorola 68000 microprocessor. The development environment was a VAX minicomputer running UNIX. Whilst at Case I attended several courses, amongst which was an advanced 'C' course run by The Instruction Set.
After promotion, the next project that I worked on at Case, was the production of a frame relay feeder product. I led the small development team, and was responsible for the analysis, design and associated documentation as well as for a demonstration product which was on show at TMA '92 in Brighton. The product was released successfully and within the allotted time scales. The coding was all in 'C' for the Motorola 68020 microprocessor, and the development environment was a VAX minicomputer running UNIX. I also had responsibility for specifying, introducing, and running a Novell LAN.
